title: 105_hr4539
content: The "Consular Review Act of 1998" establishes a Board of Visa Appeals under the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Secretary of State shall establish a Board of Visa Appeals composed of 5 members, with no more than 2 being consular officers. The Board has authority to review discretionary decisions of consular officers regarding immigrant and nonimmigrant visas, petitions, and waiver applications under section 212. The Board of Visa Appeals, established by the Secretary of State, has the authority to review consular officers' decisions on visas, petitions, and waiver applications. The Board can overrule or remand decisions if they are contrary to the evidence presented. Proceedings before the Board must follow regulations set by the Secretary of State, ensuring notice and review process for all parties involved. The Board of Visa Appeals can review consular officers' decisions on visas, petitions, and waiver applications. The Board must be provided with a written record of the proceedings and decision, and the appellant must be given notice of the Board proceedings. The appellant may also be represented at no expense. The Board of Visa Appeals can review decisions on visas, petitions, and waiver applications. The appellant may choose counsel at no expense and must request a review within 60 days. Interested parties include petitioners of immigrant and nonimmigrant visa petitions. The Board of Visa Appeals can review decisions on visas, petitions, and waiver applications for various categories of nonimmigrant students, international agency sponsors, and treaty investors/traders in the United States. Requests for review are limited to once every 24 months, and this section does not limit further administrative or judicial review rights. The Secretary of State will charge a fee for requests to the Board for review, enough to cover administration costs. The effective dates for the amendment are specified, with regulations and Board member appointments to follow within specific timeframes. The Act includes technical amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act, allowing interested parties to inspect records of proceedings. Amendments also include changes to Section 104(a)(1) and updates to the table of contents.
